intro: Abacopteris glandulosa, commonly known as the sticky matted rock-rose, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of southwestern Australia. It is characterized by its compact, low-growing habit with dense clusters of small, glandular leaves. The plant produces showy, tubular flowers that are typically pink or red, which attract nectar-feeding insects. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures. Due to its unique appearance and ecological role, it is often cultivated in xeriscapes and rock gardens.

This plant is typically found in moist, shaded environments and is often associated with rocky or forested areas. The genus Abacopteris is known for its unique morphological features, including the presence of glandular structures on its stems. Its classification reflects its evolutionary position within the ancient lineage of vascular plants.

It thrives in sandy soils along the shorelines and is commonly found in dune environments. This plant is well adapted to salt spray and wind, making it a key component of coastal vegetation. It is also occasionally found in inland areas with similar ecological conditions. Its distribution is closely linked to the specific microclimates and soil types of the Australian coastline.
